snippet: Officials said they were still at the start of an inquiry on the attack at the Boston Marathon that killed three people and hurt more than 170, using what were likely kitchen pressure cookers set up to shoot shrapnel.
abstract: Officials say explosives that killed three people and hurt more than 170 during Boston Marathon were likely rudimentary devices made from ordinary kitchen pressure cookers loaded with shrapnel; say bombs were rigged to severely maim, and were probably hidden inside duffel bags or backpacks and left on street or sidewalk near finish line; Pres Obama says Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating attack as 'act of terrorism.'

byline.original: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, ERIC SCHMITT and SCOTT SHANE
byline.contributor: Katharine Q. Seelye reported from Boston, and Scott Shane and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Reporting was contributed by John Eligon, Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Jess Bidgood from Boston, Michael Cooper and William K. Rashbaum from New York, and Mark Landler and Michael S. Schmidt from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Officials said they were still at the start of an inquiry on the attack at the Boston Marathon that killed three people and hurt more than 170, using what were likely kitchen pressure cookers set up to shoot shrapnel.

headline.seo: Bomb Details Emerge in Boston Case
headline.main: Boston Bombs Were Loaded to Maim
headline.print_headline: Boston Bombs Were Loaded to Maim, Officials Say
headline.sub: Lacking Suspects, Authorities Ask for Photos and Video
